{{italic title}} {| class="infobox" style="width: 25em; text-align: left; font-size: 90%;" |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center; font-size: large;" | '''''The Naked Scientists''''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:NS Logo.jpg|200px||{{Deletable image-caption|1=Friday, 11 January 2008}}]] --> ''The Naked Scientists Radio Show & Podcast'' [[File:The Naked Scientists, logo.png|thumb|center]] |- !Format |Science [[talk radio]] / [[podcast]] |- !Running time |60 minutes |- !Country |{{Flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[United Kingdom]] |- !Language |English |- !Broadcast time |Sundays, 6-7 P.M. UK time |- ! Broadcast area | BBC Radio in the [[East of England]] Worldwide Online and as a [[podcast]] [[BBC Radio 5 Live|BBC 5 Live]] across the UK [[Radio National|ABC Radio National]] across Australia Radio New Zealand National Talk Radio 702 / 567 Cape Talk, South Africa |- ! Frequency |[[BBC Radio 5 Live|BBC 5 Live]] - 693 and 909 MW
[[BBC Radio Cambridgeshire]] - 96.0 & 95.7 [[FM broadcasting|FM]]
[[BBC Radio Norfolk]] - 95.1 & 104.4 FM 855 & 873 [[AM broadcasting|AM]]
Online - [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio/aod/networks/cam/live.shtml BBC Radio Player]
[http://www.thenakedscientists.com/HTML/podcasts/ As a podcast] |- ! Website | {{URL|www.thenakedscientists.com}} |} '''''The Naked Scientists''''' is a one-hour audience-interactive [[science]] radio talk show broadcast live by the [[BBC]] in the [[East of England]], nationally by BBC Radio 5 Live and internationally on [[Radio National|ABC Radio National, Australia]]; it is also distributed globally as a [[podcast]].
The programme was created and is edited by [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]] consultant virologist [[Chris Smith (doctor)|Dr Chris Smith]]. The present ''Naked Scientists'' line up also includes science broadcaster and harpist Kat Arney and producers Georgia Mills, Adam Murphy, Katie Haylor and Izzie Clarke, with [[Peter Cowley]] adding a technology perspective
In 2009 the group appointed the first official ''Naked Scientists'' PhD student, Diana O'Carroll, to examine the educational impacts of science broadcasting and new media. O'Carroll also set up a ''Naked Scientists'' spin-off podcast, ''Naked Archaeology'', which launched in 2008. A second spin-off, ''Naked Astronomy'', featuring Cambridge University-based space scientists and astronomers, has been podcast since December 2009. Naked Astronomy also hosts the Space Boffins podcast, produced by journalists Richard Hollingham and Sue Nelson. A combined video and audio programme, ''Naked Engineering'', produced by Dave Ansell and Meera Senthilingam and supported by the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]], launched in September 2010. For Christmas 2010 the group also showcased a new video podcast strand, the ''Naked Science Scrapbook''. In 2012, a Naked Neuroscience strand was unveiled, and in 2013 the Material Chef video series, showcasing materials science, was launched.
==''Naked Scientists'' show content== Each episode of the main ''Naked Scientists'' programme is one hour long and includes a digest of topical science news stories, audience questions answered live on the air and interviews with guest scientists. These individuals join the hosts in the studio to talk about their work and to take questions live from listeners. Previous featured guests include the discoverer of the DNA fingerprint,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenakedscientists.com/html/shows/2005.12.04.htm |title=Forensics, DNA Fingerprinting and Human Origins |publisher=The Naked Scientists |date=2005-12-04 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> [[Alec Jeffreys]], the [[Astronomer Royal]] Sir [[Martin Rees]], and the co-discoverer of [[DNA]] structure, [[James D. Watson]].
The show also features on-location reports and interviews, and an ad-hoc interactive segment called ''Kitchen Science'' where listeners are encouraged to attempt a science experiment at home during the show. Kitchen Science experiments have included building a desktop [[trebuchet]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenakedscientists.com/HTML/content/kitchenscience/exp/the-trebuchet/ |title=The Trebuchet |publisher=The Naked Scientists |date=2008-11-16 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> a [[chocolate]] [[teapot]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenakedscientists.com/HTML/content/kitchenscience/exp/how-useless-is-a-chocolate-teapot/ |title=How useless is a Chocolate Teapot? |publisher=The Naked Scientists |date=2008-08-31 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> and a [[Liver]] powered [[Bottle Rocket]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenakedscientists.com/HTML/content/kitchenscience/exp/fizzes-from-peroxide/ |title=Fizzes from peroxide |publisher=The Naked Scientists |date=2008-09-21 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> The Kitchen Science segment also hosts experiments that listeners may not be able to do at home, such as generating [[X-rays]] from Sticky Tape <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenakedscientists.com/HTML/content/kitchenscience/exp/glowing-tape/ |title=Glowing tape |publisher=The Naked Scientists |date=2008-11-30 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> with Dr Carlos Camara of [[UCLA]] and testing how much fat would stop a bullet<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenakedscientists.com/HTML/content/kitchenscience/exp/how-fat-would-you-have-to-be-to-stop-a-bullet/ |title=How fat would you have to be to stop a bullet? |publisher=The Naked Scientists |date=2007-06-17 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> with researchers at [[Cambridge University]]'s [[Cavendish Laboratory]].
==Awards and prizes== ''The Naked Scientists'' have won eight national and international awards for science communication since 2006. The show won the [[Biosciences Federation]] Prize for Science Communication, 2006,<ref>[http://www.bsf.ac.uk/Media/award/sci_comm2006.htm Biosciences Federation Science Communication Award 2006] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081113175023/http://www.bsf.ac.uk/Media/award/sci_comm2006.htm |date=2008-11-13 }}</ref> the Joshua Phillips Award for Innovation in Science Engagement in 2007,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.manchestersciencefestival.com/news/article.aspx?ID=232 |title=And the winner is... |publisher=[[Manchester Science Festival]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218231113/http://www.manchestersciencefestival.com/news/article.aspx?ID=232 |archivedate=2009-02-18}}</ref> the [[Society for General Microbiology]]'s Peter Wildy Prize 2008, the [[Royal Society]] [[Kohn Award]] for 2008,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://royalsociety.org/awards/kohn-award/ |title=Royal Society Kohn Award |publisher=[[Royal Society]]}}</ref> the Best Radio Show Award at the Population Institute's 29th Global Media Awards, 2008,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.populationinstitute.org/newsroom/press-release/?id=89 |title=29th Annual Global Media Award Winners Announced |publisher=The Population Institute |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224102213/http://www.populationinstitute.org/newsroom/press-release/?id=89 |archivedate=2009-02-24}}</ref> the [[European Podcast Award]] for UK Non-Profit podcast,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.european-podcast-award.eu/european-podcast-award-0809-winners-announced-44 |title=European Podcast Award 08/09 Winners announced |date=2009-04-01 |publisher=European Podcast Award |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> the inaugural Royal College of Pathologists Furness Prize for science communication 2010 and the Society of Biology Science Communication Prize 2012.
''The Naked Scientists'' was also in the five finalists in the 2006 World Podcast Awards and received two nominations, for "best produced" and "best science and technology podcast" in the 2007 awards. It was also a top five finalist in the 2008 and 2009 awards.
Bandwidth consumed by the programme's podcast exceeds 28TB (terabytes) of downloads per month and more than 40 million copies have been downloaded since 2007.
==Other media== The Naked Scientists appeared on [[Five (TV channel)|TV Channel Five's]] [[panel game]] ''[[The What in the World? Quiz]]'' and have contributed to the 2007 [[Channel 4]] programme "The Farm Revealed". In September 2008, with the [[Open University]], the Naked Scientists launched a new UK national radio edition of their programme, ''The Naked Scientists - Up All Night'' (subsequently renamed "Breaking Science") which was broadcast on [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] for 12 months before finishing in 2009.
In November 2008, with the [[Royal Society of Chemistry]], a series entitled ''The Naked Scientists In Africa'' began on [[Channel Africa]], the [[international broadcasting]] service of the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation]]. ''The Naked Scientists in Africa'' was produced by Naked Scientist team-member Meera Senthilingam, incorporating international science news and a focus on science stories originating in, or pertinent to, African countries. This project ran until 2010.
==Scheduling changes== In August 2012, BBC East announced an impending change to the Sunday schedule, which would see the show discontinued. In response to public reaction, the head of BBC East, Mick Rawsthorne, was interviewed on national radio about the decision to end the programme. Rawsthorne explained that the ''Naked Scientists'' did not fit the station's core purpose of providing "local radio".<ref>{{cite web|last=Curry |first=Stephen |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/occams-corner/2012/nov/20/1 |title=Radio Ga Ga: BBC axes popular science radio show|newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=2012-11-20 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01nq3lx |title=BBC Radio 4 - Feedback, 09/11/2012 |publisher=[[BBC Radio 4]] |date=2012-11-11 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> However, Rawsthorne did acknowledge the quality of the ''Naked Scientists'' programming and recognised that, with Cambridge University at the heart of Cambridgeshire, special consideration should be made for science in Cambridgeshire. Consequently, the BBC reconsidered their decision to terminate the programme and developed a proposal for it to continue as well as a way for enhanced scientific coverage and content to be integrated within the other mainstream mid-week outputs of [[BBC Cambridgeshire]], significantly increasing the reach of the programme and the representation of science within the outputs of BBC Radio Cambridgeshire.
From January 2013, a new initiative involving the Naked Scientists began on BBC Radio Norfolk. A dedicated hour of science Q and A was included within the station's Tea Time output (hosted by Matthew Gudgin) on alternate Wednesday evenings from 1800-1900. Listeners call, text, tweet or email with questions on any scientific subject and the team answer them.
==ABC Radio National, Australia== From January 2013, the ''Naked Scientists'' programme also began to air across Australia on [[ABC Radio National]], initially on a Sunday morning. From January 2014 the first airing of the programme was moved to a Friday evening 10pm slot, repeated on Sundays at 1500. This show is also released as the Naked Scientists Podcast.
==BBC Radio 5 live Science== Launched in May 2014, ''5 live Science'' is a new weekly one-hour programme from the Naked Scientists aired by [[BBC Radio 5 Live|BBC 5 live]]. Under the banner ''5 live Science'' it's a newly formatted version of the show produced by the Naked Scientists team and fronted by [[Chris Smith, The Naked Scientist|Dr Chris Smith]]; it airs nationally every Sunday morning. The programme is also released as a podcast under the same name.
==Internship Programme== The Naked Scientists regularly host paid internships including positions supported in the past by Cambridge University, the Royal Academy of Engineering, MRC (Medical Research Council), STFC (Science and Technology Facilities Council), the UK's Genetics Society and the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC). The present programme targets science PhD students. Applicants are "bought out" from their research projects for two months to join the Naked Scientists team where they learn to participate in the programme-making process, including presenting, writing and publishing skills. In 2017 the Naked Scientists hosted their first international trainee when University of Western Australia PhD student Michael Wheeler joined the team, and in 2018 Virginia Tech students Marika Ottman and Vy Nguyen received support from Rolls-Royce to pursue a placement with the Naked Scientists.
==Funders and supporters== The Naked Scientists have received funding and awards from the [[Wellcome Trust]], the [[Natural Environment Research Council]], the [[Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council]] (EPSRC), Cambridge University including the Isaac Newton Trust, the [[Science and Technology Facilities Council]] (STFC), the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]], the [[Royal Society of Chemistry]] and [[Rolls-Royce Holdings|Rolls-Royce]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.thenakedscientists.com/ The Naked Scientists website] * [http://www.thenakedscientists.com/podcast|Naked Scientists Podcast]

{{Update|date=February 2011}} '''University Nord''' ({{lang-et|Akadeemia Nord}}) was a private university in [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]], established in 1991. In 2010 it joined the [[University of Tallinn]].
